name: Thiopental
summary: Thiopental (Pentothal) is an ultra–short-acting barbiturate used for induction of anesthesia and emergency seizure control.
description: Thiopental sodium, marketed under the brand name Pentothal, is an ultra–short-acting barbiturate that enhances the inhibitory effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) at the GABA-A receptor. It is used primarily for the induction of general anesthesia, procedural sedation, and rapid control of seizures in emergency situations. Its effects occur within seconds after intravenous administration but last only a few minutes due to rapid redistribution from the brain to peripheral tissues. Thiopental is a controlled substance (Schedule III in the U.S.) and has been largely replaced in many clinical settings by newer agents such as propofol.

off_label_uses: Medically induced coma for intracranial pressure control

sections.text: Potentiates the action of GABA at the GABA-A receptor, increasing chloride ion influx and hyperpolarizing neuronal membranes, resulting in CNS depression.

adult.intravenous: Induction: 3–5 mg/kg IV; repeat doses or infusion as needed for short-term anesthesia.

items: Powder for injection: reconstituted to various concentrations (e.g., 2.5%)

sections.text: Onset within 30–40 seconds; duration of anesthesia is 5–10 minutes due to redistribution.

other: Use with extreme caution in patients with cardiovascular instability
Avoid in patients with acute porphyria
Requires airway management capability during administration

sections.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks; crosses placenta and may cause neonatal depression
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; caution advised
sections.geriatrics: Lower doses recommended due to increased sensitivity

sections.text: Not applicable for single-use induction; prolonged infusions should be tapered to prevent withdrawal symptoms.

items: Once widely used for anesthesia induction, now largely replaced by propofol
Ultra–short duration makes it useful for brief procedures
Contraindicated in porphyria due to risk of triggering acute attacks
